At that time, Bodhisattva Vajra Treasury, wanting to restate this meaning, spoke a verse, saying:
The bodhisattva has already purified the fifth stage, contemplating phenomena as signless and without self-nature,
Without arising, without birth, always tranquil, with a nature originally pure and free from conceptual proliferation.
Also without acceptance or rejection, like illusions and so forth, existence and non-existence are non-dual, free from discrimination;
Contemplating in accordance with the nature of phenomena in this way, by this wisdom one enters the sixth stage.
Fully endowed with the wisdom of sharp and compliant forbearance, contemplating the arising and ceasing characteristics of all worlds;
Knowing that the world arises due to the grasping of self, apart from the grasping of self, the world does not exist.
Correctly penetrating the emptiness of dependent arising, without destroying the functioning of provisional establishment and combination;
Without action, without receiver, without life-principle, the activities arise everywhere like clouds.
Ignorance is the lack of knowledge of the truths, the actions and fruits created by delusion are called formations,
The initial mind at birth is called consciousness, the other aggregates that arise together are called name-and-form,
The growth of these is called the six sense bases. The union of the three is contact, and feeling arises together with it.
Delight in feeling is called craving. Craving increases to grasping. Contaminated actions are becoming. The arising of the aggregates is birth.
The ripening of the aggregates is called old age, and the disintegration of the aggregates is death. Thus the great mass of pure suffering is accumulated.
Understanding that the three realms are only mind, the twelve links exist based on the mind;
Birth and death are all created by the mind. If the mind ceases, birth and death are extinguished.
The two kinds of activities created by ignorance, due to the cause of delusion and action;
Thus up to old age and death, from this suffering arises endlessly.
The condition of ignorance is called the activities. Without cutting off, it also helps to accomplish;
Because of this non-existence, the activities cease. Without further support, the rest are also like this.
Delusion, craving, and grasping are the flow of afflictions. Action and becoming are karma. The rest are all suffering;
Ignorance and karmic formations are the past, consciousness up to feeling are the present,

Because karmic formations and so forth arise from causes and conditions, when conditions are separated, they are cut off and thus are empty by nature;
Ignorance as a condition is bondage to birth. When conditions are separated, bondage is removed.
Following ignorance, various existences arise. If one does not follow, various existences are cut off;

The three periods of time, the three sufferings, and the causes and conditions of birth, the continuous bondage of arising and ceasing, in accordance with the inexhaustible.

If a bodhisattva has well perfected the path of practice in the sixth ground and wishes to enter the bodhisattva's seventh ground, he should enter by means of the ten kinds of marvelous skillful wisdom that lead to the unsurpassed advanced path of practice.

They understand that the Dharma body of all Buddhas has the nature of being like space, yet are able to manifest the adornment of their bodies with wondrous physical characteristics and marks;
Moreover, they know that the inherent nature of the Buddhas' sounds is tranquil and inexpressible, yet they are able to give rise to the adornments of all the distinctions in sounds and tones;

They understand that in a single instant the Buddhas suddenly realize the three times, yet they are able to follow and manifest various appearances, numbers of eons, and so forth, observing the inclinations of sentient beings' minds.

In this way, the Bodhisattvas, through these ten kinds of wondrous skillful means and wisdom, draw forth the uncommon superior practices for advancing on the path, and enter from the sixth ground into the seventh ground.
Only the Buddha's disciples!

The bodhisattvas dwelling in this ground of Far-reaching, in these ten perfections, in an instant all attain the four kinds of embracing activities and the four kinds of empowerment, the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment, and the three gates of liberation. If he abandons all deliberate effort, from the seventh ground he enters the eighth ground, riding the pure vehicle of the bodhisattva, traveling through the world, knowing the afflictions and faults, yet not being defiled, because he has already surpassed them.

The bodhisattva who abides in this bodhisattva's seventh ground, for the most part surpasses all afflictions such as greed. When the bodhisattvas cultivate this ground of far-reaching, they should be said to be neither with afflictions nor without afflictions.

Because one still has not attained the Buddha's wisdom that one aspires for, one should not say that one is one who has no afflictions.
